item.title: CSCI 442 student environment
item.description: What is Docker Â§ Docker is a tool that allows developers to easily deploy their applications in a sandbox (called containers) to run on the host operating system.

item.title: Setting Up The Docker Container
item.description: Create your directory to store your projects in Â§ We recommend creating a directory on your computer called OS_Projects, in which your projects will be synced with your Docker container.

item.title: Setting Up Your Projects Inside the Docker Container
item.description: Before following this guide, you need access to your Docker containerâ€™s terminal in order to run these commands. The reference guide, Opening a Docker Containerâ€™s Terminal will help with this.

item.title: Additional Docker-foo
item.description: Checking if your docker container is running Â§ Once you have run your docker image, you can check whether it is running using docker ps in your terminal.

item.title: Avoiding Data Loss and Other Important Notes
item.description: Graceful Exit Â§ While your changes will most likely be saved to disk, it is never good to risk an abrupt shutdown of anything when avoidable. There may be some process that is accessing a file, and an abrupt shutdown may corrupt that file (and your work).

item.title: Opening a Docker Container's Terminal
item.description: VSCode Terminal Â§ Follow the instructions under Setup. On the top header bar, click Terminal > New Terminal. What is shown on my computer as Ctrl+Shift+` is the keyboard shortcut I can use to create a new terminal.

item.title: Using Visual Studio Code
item.description: If you prefer a graphical IDE, VSCode has excellent support for Docker. Setup Â§ Prerequisites Â§ Youâ€™ve followed the first step for setup, Setting Up The Docker Container.
